conclusion: Shadows are formed when an object blocks a light source. The size and position of the shadow depend on the relative positions of the light source, the object, and the surface where the shadow is cast.
When the light source moves further away from the objects, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes, affecting the size and position of the shadows.

premise: When the light source moves further away from the objects, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes.
conclusion: As the light source moves further away, the angle of the light rays becomes more parallel. This results in the shadows becoming smaller because the light rays are less spread out.

premise: When the light source moves further away from the objects, the angle at which the light rays hit the objects changes.
conclusion: The shadows will also move closer to the objects that cast them. This is because the light rays are now hitting the objects at a more direct angle, reducing the distance between the objects and their shadows.
